data.title: Existence and Regularity of Spheres Minimising the Canham–Helfrich Energy
data.meta_description: We prove the existence and regularity of minimisers for the Canham–Helfrich energy in the class of weak (possibly branched and bubbled) immersions of
data.text:
The basic structural and functional unit of all known living organisms is the cell. The interior material of a cell, the cytoplasm, is enclosed by biological membranes. Most of the cell membranes of living organisms are made of a lipid bilayer, which is a thin polar membrane consisting of two opposite oriented layers of lipid molecules.

In 1970, in order to explain the biconcave shape of red blood cells, Canham [7] proposed a bending energy density dependent on the squared mean curvature.

Three years later Helfrich proposed the following curvature elastic energy per unit area of a closed lipid bilayer [18, Equation (12)]:

$$\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2}k_c(H - c_0)^2 + {\bar{k}}_c K, \end{aligned}$$

(1.1)

where H is the mean curvature, K is the Gauss curvature, \(c_0\) is the so-called spontaneous curvature, and \(k_c, {\bar{k}}_c\) are the curvature elastic moduli. The values of the parameters can be measured experimentally (for example see [11, 13] for \(c_{0}\), and [30] for \(k_{c}\)). The constant \(\bar{k}_c\) is not important for the purpose of this paper as by the Gauss–Bonnet Theorem, the integrated Gauss curvature is a topological constant.

Lipid bilayers are very thin compared to their lateral dimensions, thus are usually modelled as surfaces. Suppose the surface and hence the membrane is represented by a smooth isometric embedding \(\vec \Phi : {\mathbb {S}}^2 \rightarrow {\mathbb {R}}^3\) of the 2-sphere \({\mathbb {S}}^2\). We will be concerned with the following integrated version of (1.1):

$$\begin{aligned} {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}(\vec \Phi ) := \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 } (H - c_0)^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu = \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 } \left( H^2 -2c_0H +1\right) \, \mathrm{d}\mu , \end{aligned}$$

(1.2)

where again, H is the mean curvature, \(c_0\) is a constant, and \(\mu \) is the Radon measure corresponding to the pull back of the Euclidean metric along \(\vec \Phi \). The integral in (1.2) is known as Canham–Helfrich energy. It is also referred to as Canham–Evans–Helfrich or just Helfrich energy. Its most important reduction is the Willmore energy, where \(c_0 = 0\). Due to its simplicity and fundamental nature, the Willmore energy appears in many areas of science and technology, and has been studied a lot in the past. Its first appearances were found in the works of Poisson [31] in 1814 and Germain [14] in 1821. It was finally brought onto physical grounds by Kirchhoff [22] in 1850 as the free energy of an elastic membrane. In the early 20th century, Blaschke considered the Willmore energy in the context of differential geometry and proved its conformal invariance, see for instance [6].

The difference between Willmore energy and Canham–Helfrich energy comes from the constant \(c_0\), known as spontaneous curvature. According to Seifert [36], it is mainly caused by asymmetry between the two layers of the membrane. Geometrically, the asymmetric area difference between the two layers is given by the total mean curvature, that is the integrated mean curvature. This is due to the fact that the infinitesimal variation of the area, that is the area difference between two nearby surfaces, is the total mean curvature. Döbereiner et al. [12] observed that spontaneous curvature may also arise from differences in the chemical properties of the aqueous solution on the two sides of the lipid bilayer. Many approaches about how to derive the Canham–Helfrich energy density as the energy density of a lipid bilayer have appeared in the literature. We refer to Seifert [36] for more details.

Our goal is to minimise the Canham–Helfrich energy as well as to study the regularity of minimisers (and more generally of critical points). In the language of the calculus of variations we are concerned with Problem 1.2, as stated in Bernard et al. [5, Introduction, Problem (P1)]. Given a smooth embedding \(\vec \Phi : {\mathbb {S}}^2 \rightarrow {\mathbb {R}}^3\) denote by \({{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}\vec \Phi =\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} \mathrm{d}\mu \) the area of the surface \(\vec \Phi ({\mathbb {S}}^2)\) and by \({{\,\mathrm{Vol}\,}}\vec \Phi \) the enclosed volume.

Remark 1.1

A candidate embedding \(\vec \Phi _0\) which achieves the global minimum is called a minimiser. In general it is not unique and, more dramatically, it may not exist: later in the introduction we show that for a suitable choice of parameters the minimum is achieved by a singular immersion and it cannot be achieved by a smooth one. The constraints and the functional \({\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}\) are invariant under reparametrisation as well as rigid motions in \({\mathbb {R}}^3\). Of course, in order to have a non-empty class of competitors, the constraints have to satisfy the Euclidean isoperimetric inequality \(A_0^3 \geqslant 36 \pi V_0^2\).

Problem 1.2

Let \(c_0, A_0\), and \(V_0\) be given constants. Minimise \({\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}(\vec \Phi )\) in the class of smooth embeddings \(\vec \Phi : {\mathbb {S}}^2 \rightarrow {\mathbb {R}}^3\) subject to the constraints

$$\begin{aligned} {{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}\vec \Phi = A_0 \quad \text {and} \quad {{\,\mathrm{Vol}\,}}\vec \Phi = V_0. \end{aligned}$$

(1.3)

That is, find an embedding \(\vec \Phi _0 : {\mathbb {S}}^2 \rightarrow {\mathbb {R}}^3\) such that \({{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}\vec \Phi _0 = A_0\), \({{\,\mathrm{Vol}\,}}\vec \Phi _0 = V_0\), and

$$\begin{aligned} {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0} (\vec \Phi _0) \leqslant {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}(\vec \Phi ) \end{aligned}$$

for any other smooth embedding \(\vec \Phi : {\mathbb {S}}^2 \rightarrow {\mathbb {R}}^3\) satisfying the constraints (1.3).

Problem 1.2 is the classical formulation suggested in [11, 18]. According to Bernard et al. [5], many issues for the Canham–Helfrich energy, including Problem 1.2, remain open and form important questions that future research should address. A similar problem in the 2-dimensional case (that is closed curves in the Euclidean plane) was formulated and solved by Bellettini et al. [3] by a relaxation procedure.

While there was essentially no work on the variational theory of the Willmore energy after Blaschke’s seminal work, in 1965 Willmore [40] reintroduced this Lagrangian which is now named after him. He showed that the round sphere is a minimiser of Problem 1.2 in the special case \(c_0 = 0\) without constraints (1.3), see [41]. Simon [39] proved existence of higher genus minimisers for the Willmore energy (see also Kusner [25] and Bauer–Kuwert [2]), using the so-called ambient approach, that is convergence of surfaces is considered in the measure-theoretic sense. Rivière [32, 33] proved the analogous result with the so called parametric approach, that is based on PDE theory and functional analysis as opposed to geometric measure theory. In the present paper we shall adapt the parametric approach. The case \(c_0 = 0\) with constraints (1.3) was solved by Schygulla [35] using the ambient approach, and generalised to higher genus surfaces by Keller, the first author, and Rivière [21] using the parametric approach.

From the mathematical point of view, the spontaneous curvature \(c_0\) causes a couple of differences between the Willmore energy and the Canham–Helfrich energy. Most obviously, the Canham–Helfrich energy cannot be bounded below by a strictly positive constant, whereas the Willmore energy is bounded below by \(4\pi \), see (2.13). Secondly, while the Willmore functional is invariant under conformal transformations, the Canham–Helfrich energy is not conformally invariant. We will be concerned with yet another property that fails for the Canham–Helfrich energy due to non-negative spontaneous curvature, namely, lower semi-continuity with respect to varifold convergence; while it is well known that the Willmore functional is lower semi-continuous under varifold convergence, the Canham–Helfrich energy in general is not. Indeed, Große-Brauckmann [15, Remark (ii) on p. 550] constructed a sequence of non-compact infinite genus surfaces \(\Sigma _1, \Sigma _2, \ldots \) with constant mean curvature equal to 1 which converges in the varifold sense to a double plane \(\Sigma _\infty \). Hence, the mean curvature \(H_\infty \) of the limit \(\Sigma _\infty \) is zero and

$$\begin{aligned} 0 = \int \nolimits _{\Sigma _k} (H_k - 1)^2\eta \,d{\mathscr {H}}^2 < 2 \int \nolimits _{\Sigma _\infty } (H_\infty -1)^2\eta \,d{\mathscr {H}}^2 = 2 \int \nolimits _{\Sigma _\infty } \eta \,d{\mathscr {H}}^2 \end{aligned}$$

for any continuous non-negative, non-zero function \(\eta \) on \({\mathbb {R}}^3\) of compact support, where \({\mathscr {H}}^2\) is the 2-dimensional Hausdorff measure. Hence, the general Canham–Helfrich energy is not lower semi-continuous under varifold convergence. However, in order to solve Problem 1.2 by the so-called direct method of calculus of variations, lower semi continuity is required. According to Röger [27], it was an open question under which conditions/in which natural weak topology on the space of immersions one obtains lower semi continuity of the Canham–Helfrich energy. This is presumably the reason why Problem 1.2 was only partially solved for non-zero spontaneous curvature \(c_0\). The axisymmetric case was solved in 2013 by Choksi and Veneroni [9], who proved the existence of a minimiser of the Canham–Helfrich energy among a suitable class of axisymmetric (possibly singular) surfaces under fixed surface area and enclosed volume constraints. Five years later, Dalphin [10] showed existence of minimisers in a class of \(C^{1,1}\) surfaces whose principal curvatures are bounded by a given constant \(1/\varepsilon \). Though, in his setting, it is still unclear how to get compactness and lower semi-continuity as \(\varepsilon \) tends to zero.

As already alluded to, we tackle Problem 1.2 by the direct method of calculus of variations. The issue is of course to find a suitable class \({\mathcal {F}}_{A_0, V_0}\) of admissible maps (endowed with a suitable topology) having area \(A_0\) and enclosed volume \(V_0\) such that the Canham–Helfrich energy is lower semi-continuous and has (pre-) compact sub-levels. A natural choice is the class of weak (Sobolev) immersions in \(W^{2,2}({\mathbb {S}}^2, {\mathbb {R}}^3)\), already employed in the context of the Willmore energy for instance by Rivière [33] or Kuwert and Li [23]. We will use the space of bubble trees of weak possibly branched immersions. It will shortly become clear why we have to allow branched points and multiple bubbles.

In what follows, we denote by \( \cdot \) (resp. \(\times \)) the Euclidean scalar (resp. vector) product on \({\mathbb {R}}^{3}\).

Definition 1.3

A map \(\vec \Phi : {\mathbb {S}}^2 \rightarrow {\mathbb {R}}^3\) is called weak (possibly branched) immersion with finite total curvature if \(\vec \Phi \in W^{1, \infty }({\mathbb {S}}^2, {\mathbb {R}}^3)\) and the following holds:

1.

There exists \(C>1\) such that, for almost every \(p\in {\mathbb {S}}^{2}\),

$$\begin{aligned} C^{-1} |\mathrm{d} \vec \Phi |^{2}(p)\leqslant |\mathrm{d} \vec \Phi \times \mathrm{d} \vec \Phi |(p) \leqslant C |\mathrm{d} \vec \Phi |^{2}(p), \end{aligned}$$

(1.4)

where the norms are taken with respect to the standard metric on \({\mathbb {S}}^{2}\) and with respect to the Euclidean metric of \({\mathbb {R}}^{3}\), and where \(\mathrm{d} \vec \Phi \times \mathrm{d} \vec \Phi \) is the tensor given in local coordinates on \({\mathbb {S}}^{2}\) by

$$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{d} \vec \Phi \times \mathrm{d} \vec \Phi := 2 \partial _{x^{1}} \vec \Phi \times \partial _{x^{2}} \vec \Phi \; \mathrm{d}x^{1}\wedge \mathrm{d}x^{2} \in \wedge ^{2} T^{*} {\mathbb {S}}^{2} \otimes {\mathbb {R}}^{3}; \end{aligned}$$

2.

There exist a positive integer N and finitely many points \(b_1, \ldots , b_N \in {\mathbb {S}}^2\) such that \(\log |\mathrm{d} \vec \Phi |\in L^{\infty }_{loc} ({\mathbb {S}}^2 {\setminus } \{b_1, \ldots , b_N\})\);

3.

The Gauss map \(\vec n\), defined by

$$\begin{aligned} \vec n := \frac{\partial _{x^1} \vec \Phi \times \partial _{x^2} \vec \Phi }{|\partial _{x^1} \vec \Phi \times \partial _{x^2} \vec \Phi |} \end{aligned}$$

in any local chart x of \({\mathbb {S}}^2\), satisfies

$$\begin{aligned} \vec n \in W^{1,2}({\mathbb {S}}^2, {\mathbb {R}}^3). \end{aligned}$$

The space of weak (possibly branched) immersions with finite total curvature is denoted by \({\mathcal {F}}\).

Since by assumption \(\vec \Phi \) is a Lipschitz map, it induces an \(L^\infty \)-metric g given by

$$\begin{aligned} g(X,Y) = \mathrm{d}\vec \Phi (X) \cdot \mathrm{d}\vec \Phi (Y) \end{aligned}$$

for elements X, Y of the tangent bundle \(T{\mathbb {S}}^2\). In the usual way (see for instance [16, 1.2]), the \(L^\infty \)-metric g induces a Radon measure \(\mu \) on \({\mathbb {S}}^2\) which is mutually absolutely continuous to the 2-dimensional Hausdorff measure on \({\mathbb {S}}^2\).

Using Müller–Svěrák theory of weak isothermic charts [29] and Hélein’s moving frame technique [17] one can prove the following proposition (see for instance [34])

Proposition 1.4

Let \(\vec {\Phi }\in {\mathcal {F}}\) be a weak (possibly branched) immersion of \({\mathbb {S}}^2\) into \({\mathbb {R}}^{3}\). Then there exists a bilipschitz homeomorphism \(\Psi \) of \({\mathbb {S}}^2\) such that \(\vec {\Phi }\circ \Psi \) is weakly conformal; it satisfies almost everywhere on \({\mathbb {S}}^2\)

$$\begin{aligned} \left\{ \begin{array}{l} |\partial _{x^{1}}(\vec {\Phi }\circ \Psi )|^{2}=|\partial _{x^{2}}(\vec {\Phi }\circ \Psi )|^2\quad \\ \partial _{x^{1}}(\vec {\Phi }\circ \Psi ) \cdot \partial _{x^{2}}(\vec {\Phi }\circ \Psi )=0, \end{array} \right. \end{aligned}$$

where x is a local arbitrary conformal chart on \({\mathbb {S}}^2\) for the standard metric. Moreover \(\vec {\Phi }\circ \Psi \) is in \(W^{1,\infty }({\mathbb {S}}^2, {\mathbb {R}}^{3}) \cap W^{2,2}_{loc} ({\mathbb {S}}^2 {\setminus } \{b_{1},\ldots , b_{N} \}, {\mathbb {R}}^{3} )\).

Remark 1.5

In view of Proposition 1.4, a careful reader could wonder why we do not work with conformal\(W^{2,2}\) weak, possibly branched, immersions only and why we do not impose for the membership in \({{\mathcal {F}}}\), \(\vec {\Phi }\) to be conformal from the beginning. The reason why it is technically convenient not to impose conformality from the beginning is to allow for general perturbations in the variational problem, which do not have to respect infinitesimally the conformal condition.

The reason that we chose the class \({\mathcal {F}}\) as above is the following theorem of the first author and Rivière [28, Theorem 1.5] (see also [8]):

Theorem 1.6

Suppose \(\vec \Phi _1, \vec \Phi _2,\ldots \) is a sequence in \({\mathcal {F}}\) of conformal weak (possibly branched) immersions such that

$$\begin{aligned} \limsup _{k\rightarrow \infty }\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2}1+|\mathrm{d} \vec n_{k}|^2\,\mathrm{d}\mu _{k} < \infty , \qquad \liminf _{k\rightarrow \infty } {{\,\mathrm{diam}\,}}\vec \Phi _k[{\mathbb {S}}^2]>0, \end{aligned}$$

where \(\vec n_{k}\) are the Gauss maps, \(\mu _{k}\) are the corresponding Radon measures, and \({{\,\mathrm{diam}\,}}\vec \Phi _k[{\mathbb {S}}^2] := \sup _{a, b \in {\mathbb {S}}^2}|\vec \Phi (a) - \vec \Phi (b)|\).

Then, after passing to a subsequence, there exist a family \(\Psi _k\) of bilipschitz homeomorphisms of \({\mathbb {S}}^2\), a positive integer N, sequences \(f_k^1,\ldots ,f_k^N\) of positive conformal diffeomorphisms of \({\mathbb {S}}^2\), \(\vec \xi _\infty ^1,\ldots ,\vec \xi _\infty ^N \in {\mathcal {F}}\), non-negative integers \(N_1,\ldots ,N_N\), and finitely many points on the sphere

$$\begin{aligned} \{b^{i,j}:j=1,\ldots ,N_i,\,i=1,\ldots , N\}\subset {\mathbb {S}}^2, \end{aligned}$$

such that

$$\begin{aligned} \vec \Phi _k \circ \Psi _k \rightarrow \vec f_\infty \qquad \text {as } k \rightarrow \infty \text { strongly in } C^0({\mathbb {S}}^2, {\mathbb {R}}^3) \end{aligned}$$

(1.5)

for some \(\vec f_\infty \in W^{1, \infty }({\mathbb {S}}^2, {\mathbb {R}}^3)\) and

$$\begin{aligned} \vec \Phi _k \circ f^i_k \rightharpoonup \vec \xi _ \infty ^i\qquad \text {as }k\rightarrow \infty \text { weakly in } W^{2,2}_{\mathrm {loc}}({\mathbb {S}}^2{\setminus }\{b^{i,1},\ldots ,b^{i,N_i}\},{\mathbb {R}}^3) \end{aligned}$$

for \(i = 1,\ldots ,N\). Moreover,

$$\begin{aligned} \sum _{i = 1}^N \int \nolimits _ {{\mathbb {S}}^2}1\, \mathrm{d}\mu _ {\vec \xi _\infty ^i} = \lim _{k \rightarrow \infty } \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} 1 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{k}. \end{aligned}$$

The theorem already gives (pre-)compactness, a notion of convergence, and lower semi-continuity (actually, continuity) of the third summand in (1.2) of the Canham–Helfrich energy, that is of the area functional. Indeed, \(\vec T := (\vec f_\infty , \vec \xi _\infty ^1, \ldots , \vec \xi _\infty ^N)\) forms a bubble tree, see Definition 3.2. In particular, the limit \(\vec T\) is not in the class \({\mathcal {F}}\) anymore. At a rough informal level, a non-expert reader can think of a bubble tree \(\vec T := (\vec f, \vec \xi ^1, \ldots , \vec \xi ^N)\) as a “pearl necklace” where each “pearl” corresponds to the image of a possibly branched weak immersion \(\vec \xi ^i({\mathbb {S}}^{2})\) and \(\vec f\) is a Lipschitz map from \({\mathbb {S}}^{2}\) to \({\mathbb {R}}^{3}\) “parametrising” the whole pearl necklace, in particular \(\vec f({\mathbb {S}}^{2})=\bigcup _{i=1}^{N} \vec \xi ^i({\mathbb {S}}^{2})\). To get a better understanding of why we obtain a bubble tree in the limit, we will look at an example of Problem 1.2. Let

$$\begin{aligned} c_0 = 1, \qquad A_0 = 2{{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}{\mathbb {S}}^2, \qquad V_0 = 2 {{\,\mathrm{Vol}\,}}{\mathbb {S}}^2. \end{aligned}$$

Then, the infimum in Problem 1.2 is achieved by the bubble tree \(\vec T = (\vec f, \vec {\mathrm{Id}}_{{\mathbb {S}}^2}, \vec {\mathrm{Id}}_{{\mathbb {S}}^2})\) of twice the unit sphere. Indeed, \({\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}(\vec T) = 0\) and \({\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}(\vec \Phi ) \geqslant 0\) for any other smooth immersion \(\vec \Phi \) of \({\mathbb {S}}^2\) into \({\mathbb {R}}^3\), so \(\vec T\) achieves the infimum. A minimising sequence \(\vec {\Phi }_{k}({\mathbb {S}}^{2})\) of smoothly embedded spheres converging to such a bubble tree can be achieved by gluing \((1+ 1/k) {{\mathbb {S}}}^{2}\) to \((1- 1/k) {{\mathbb {S}}}^{2}\) via a small catenoidal neck of size 2/k. Notice also that if \(\vec \Phi \) satisfies \({\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}(\vec \Phi ) = 0\), then the image \(\vec \Phi [{\mathbb {S}}^2]\) is the unit sphere by a classical theorem of Hopf [19].

Getting a bubble tree in the limit is in accordance with the earlier result on existence of minimisers by Choksi and Veneroni [9] in the axisymmetric case: indeed the minimiser in [9, Theorem 1] is made by a finite union of axisymmetric surfaces.

Moreover, the bubbling phenomenon is also known as budding transition in biology and has been recorded with video microscopy, see Seifert [36] or Seifert, Berndl, and Lipowsky [37].

In Chapter 3 we sharpen Theorem 1.6 in a way that we get lower semi-continuity for the Canham–Helfrich functional. This can be seen as a possible answer to the aforementioned open question raised by Röger [27]. In Chapter 4 we compute the Euler–Lagrange equation for the Canham–Helfrich energy in divergence form. Moreover, we prove that all the weak branched conformal immersions of a minimising bubble tree (actually more generally for a critical bubble tree) are smooth away from their branch points. Our proof is based on the regularity theory for Willmore surfaces developed by Rivière [32]. This relies on conservation laws discovered by Rivière [32] in the context of the Willmore energy and adjusted by Bernard [4] for the Canham–Helfrich energy. We get the following final result.

Theorem 1.7

Suppose \(c_0 \in {\mathbb {R}}\), \(A_0, V_0 > 0\), and \(A_0^3 \geqslant 36 \pi V_0^2\).

Then, there exist a positive integer N and weak branched conformal immersions of finite total curvature \(\vec \Phi _1, \ldots , \vec \Phi _N \in {\mathcal {F}}\) such that \(\cup _{i=1}^{N} \vec \Phi _{i}({\mathbb {S}}^{2})\) is connected,

$$\begin{aligned} \inf _{\begin{array}{c} \vec \Phi \in {\mathcal {F}} \\ {{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}\vec \Phi = A_0 \\ {{\,\mathrm{Vol}\,}}\vec \Phi = V_0 \end{array}} {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}(\vec \Phi ) = \sum _{i = 1}^N {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}(\vec \Phi _i) \end{aligned}$$

(1.6)

and

$$\begin{aligned} \sum _{i = 1}^N {{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}\vec \Phi _i = A_0, \qquad \sum _{i = 1}^N {{\,\mathrm{Vol}\,}}\vec \Phi _i = V_0. \end{aligned}$$

Moreover, for each \(i \in \{1, \ldots , N\}\) there exist a non-negative integer \(N^i\) and finitely many points \(b^{i,1},\ldots ,b^{i,N^i} \in {\mathbb {S}}^2\) such that \(\vec \Phi _i\) is a \(C^{\infty }\) immersion of \({\mathbb {S}}^2 {\setminus } \{b^{i,1}, \ldots , b^{i, N^i}\}\) into \({\mathbb {R}}^3\) and \(b^{i,1},\ldots ,b^{i,N^i}\) are branch points for \(\vec \Phi _i\).

Furthermore, there exists a constant \(\varepsilon _{4.4}(A_0, V_0)>0\) such that if \(|c_0| < \varepsilon _{4.4}(A_0, V_0)\), then \(N = 1\) and \(\vec \Phi := \vec \Phi _1\) is a smooth embedding of \({\mathbb {S}}^2\) into \({\mathbb {R}}^3\).

Proof

Let \(\vec \Phi _1, \vec \Phi _2, \ldots \) be a minimising sequence of (1.6). There holds

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 } H_{\vec \Phi _k}^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _{k}}= & {} \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 } 2(H_{\vec \Phi _{k}} - c_0)^2 - (H_{\vec \Phi _k} - 2c_0)^2 + 2c_0^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _{k}} \nonumber \\\leqslant & {} 2{\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}(\vec \Phi _k) +2c_0^2A_0, \end{aligned}$$

(1.7)

where \(H_{\vec \Phi _k}\) is the mean curvature corresponding to \(\vec \Phi _k\), see (2.3). By the Gauss–Bonnet theorem (see (2.6) for the precise statement in case of weak branched immersions and (2.8) for the estimate below),

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 } |\mathrm{d} \vec n_{\vec \Phi _{k}}|^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _{k}} \leqslant 4 \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 }H_{\vec \Phi _k}^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _{k}} \end{aligned}$$

and thus

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 } 1 + |\mathrm{d} \vec n_{\vec \Phi _{k}}|^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _{k}} \leqslant 8{\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}(\vec \Phi _k) + (1+8c_0^2)A_0, \end{aligned}$$

which means the first inequality of (3.17) is satisfied. Moreover, (2.10) implies the second inequality of (3.17). Hence, we can apply Theorem 3.3, Theorem 4.3, Lemma 4.4, (2.13) and (2.12) to conclude the proof. \(\quad \square \)

Remark 1.8

The arguments in the proof of Theorem 1.7 yield also that the minimum of \({\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}\) is achieved in the class of bubble trees of possibly branched weak immersions, by a bubble tree of possibly branched immersions which are smooth out of the branch points.

A more general form of the Canham–Helfrich energy is given by

$$\begin{aligned} {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha , \rho }(\vec \Phi ) := \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} (H_{\vec \Phi } - c_0)^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi } + \alpha {{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}\vec \Phi + \rho {{\,\mathrm{Vol}\,}}\vec \Phi , \end{aligned}$$

for \(\vec \Phi \in {\mathcal {F}}\), where the parameter \(\alpha \geqslant 0\) is referred to as tensile stress, and \(\rho \geqslant 0\) as osmotic pressure. We get the following solution of Problem (P2) from the introduction in [5]:

Theorem 1.9

Suppose \(c_0 \in {\mathbb {R}}\), \(\alpha > 0\), and \(\rho \geqslant 0\). Then, it holds that

$$\begin{aligned} \inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}} {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha , \rho }(\vec \Phi ) \leqslant 4\pi . \end{aligned}$$

Moreover, if the inequality is strict, then there exist \(\vec \Phi _0 \in {\mathcal {F}}\), a positive integer \(N_0\), and points \(b_1, \ldots , b_{N_0} \in {\mathbb {S}}^2\) such that

$$\begin{aligned} \inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}} {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha , \rho }(\vec \Phi ) = {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha , \rho }(\vec \Phi _0), \end{aligned}$$

and \(\vec \Phi _0\) is a \(C^{\infty }\) immersion of \({\mathbb {S}}^2 {\setminus } \{b_1,\ldots ,b_{N_0}\}\) into \({\mathbb {R}}^3\) and \(b_1,\ldots ,b_{N_0}\) are branch points.

Furthermore, if \(|c_0| < \sqrt{\alpha }\), then \(\vec \Phi _0\) is a smooth embedding.

Proof

Taking \(\vec \Phi _k = \frac{1}{k} {\mathbb {S}}^2\) for each integer k leads to

$$\begin{aligned} \inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}} {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha , \rho }(\vec \Phi ) \leqslant \liminf _{k\rightarrow \infty } {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha , \rho }(\vec \Phi _{k}) = \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 } H_{{\mathbb {S}}^2}^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} = 4\pi , \end{aligned}$$

which proves the first statement. Now assume \(\vec \Phi _1, \vec \Phi _2, \ldots \) is a sequence in \({\mathcal {F}}\) such that

$$\begin{aligned} \lim _{k \rightarrow \infty } {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha , \rho }(\vec \Phi _k) = \inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}} {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha , \rho }(\vec \Phi ) < 4\pi . \end{aligned}$$

As \(\alpha > 0\), we have \(\sup _{k} {{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}\vec \Phi _{k}<\infty \) and thus, using (1.7), also \(\sup _{k} \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 } H_{\vec \Phi _k}^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _{k}}<\infty \).

A simple contradiction argument using (2.10) now leads to

$$\begin{aligned} \liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty } {{\,\mathrm{diam}\,}}\vec \Phi _k[{\mathbb {S}}^2] > 0, \end{aligned}$$

as otherwise we would have

$$\begin{aligned} \lim _{k \rightarrow \infty } {{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}\vec \Phi _k = 0, \qquad \lim _{k \rightarrow \infty } {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha , \rho }(\vec \Phi _k) = \lim _{k \rightarrow \infty } \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 } H_{\vec \Phi _k}^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _{k}} \geqslant 4\pi . \end{aligned}$$

Therefore, analogously to the proof of Theorem 1.7, we can apply Theorem 3.3 to obtain an integer N and \(\vec \Phi _1, \ldots , \vec \Phi _N \in {\mathcal {F}}\) such that

$$\begin{aligned} \inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}} {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha , \rho }(\vec \Phi ) = \sum _{i = 1}^N{\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha , \rho }(\vec \Phi _i). \end{aligned}$$

Obviously,

$$\begin{aligned} {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha , \rho }(\vec \Phi _1) \leqslant \sum _{i = 1}^N{\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha , \rho }(\vec \Phi _i), \end{aligned}$$

and since there are no constraints, we simply get \(N=1\). Letting \(\vec \Phi _0 := \vec \Phi _1\), we infer from (1.7) that in the case that \(|c_0| \leqslant \sqrt{\alpha }\),

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 } H_{\vec {\Phi }_0}^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _0} \leqslant 2{\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}(\vec \Phi _k) +2c_0^2 {{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}\vec \Phi _0[{\mathbb {S}}^2] \leqslant 2{\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha , \rho }(\vec \Phi _0) < 8\pi . \end{aligned}$$

The conclusion follows from Theorem 4.3, and (2.12). \(\quad \square \)

In this chapter we will prove the compactness of sequences with uniformly bounded Willmore energy and area as well as lower semi-continuity of the Canham–Helfrich energy under this convergence, see Theorem 3.3. The proof of Theorem 3.3 will build on top of [28] and the next Lemma 3.1 which establishes the convergence of the constraints and the lower semi-continuity of the Willmore energy away from the branch points (Lemma 3.1 should be compared with [34, Lemma 5.2]).

Lemma 3.1

(Convergence outside the branch points) Suppose \(\vec \xi _1, \vec \xi _2,\ldots \in {\mathcal {F}}_{{\mathbb {S}}^2}\) is a sequence of weak branched conformal immersions with finite total curvature of the 2-sphere \({\mathbb {S}}^2\) into \({\mathbb {R}}^3\), \(\mu _1,\mu _2,\ldots \) are the corresponding Radon measures on \({\mathbb {S}}^2\), \(\vec n_1, \vec n_2, \ldots \) are the corresponding Gauss maps,

$$\begin{aligned} \sup _{k \in {\mathbb {N}}}\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2}|\mathrm{d} \vec n_k|^2\,\mathrm{d}\mu _k< \infty , \end{aligned}$$

(3.1)

there exists \(\vec \xi _\infty \in {\mathcal {F}}_{{\mathbb {S}}^2}\), a positive integer N, and \(b_1,\ldots ,b_N \in {\mathbb {S}}^2\) such that

$$\begin{aligned}&\sup _{k \in {\mathbb {N}}} \Vert \log |\mathrm{d} \vec \xi _k|\Vert _{L^\infty _{\mathrm {loc}}({\mathbb {S}}^2{\setminus }\{b_1,\ldots ,b_N\})} < \infty , \end{aligned}$$

(3.2)

$$\begin{aligned}&\vec \xi _k \rightharpoonup \vec \xi _\infty \qquad \text { as }k\rightarrow \infty \text { weakly in } W^{2,2}_{\mathrm {loc}}({\mathbb {S}}^2{\setminus }\{b_1,\ldots ,b_N\},{\mathbb {R}}^3). \end{aligned}$$

(3.3)

Then, there exists a sequence of positive numbers \(s_1,s_2,\ldots \) converging to zero such that

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} 1 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _\infty&= \lim _{k\rightarrow \infty }\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2{\setminus } \bigcup _{i=1}^NB_{s_k}(b_i)} 1 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _k \end{aligned}$$

(3.4)

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H_{\infty }\,\mathrm{d}\mu _\infty&= \lim _{k\rightarrow \infty }\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2{\setminus } \bigcup _{i=1}^NB_{s_k}(b_i)}H_{k}\,\mathrm{d}\mu _k \end{aligned}$$

(3.5)

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} \vec n_ \infty \cdot \vec \xi _ \infty \,\mathrm{d}\mu _ \infty&= \lim _{k\rightarrow \infty } \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2 {\setminus } \bigcup _{i=1}^NB_{s_k}(b_i)} \vec n_k \cdot \vec \xi _k \,\mathrm{d}\mu _k, \end{aligned}$$

(3.6)

where the balls are taken with respect to the geodesic distance on the standard \({\mathbb {S}}^2\), \(\mu _ \infty \) and \(\vec n_\infty \) are the Radon measure and the Gauss map corresponding to \(\vec \xi _ \infty \), and the \(H_k\)’s and \(H_\infty \) are the mean curvatures corresponding to the \(\vec \xi _k\)’s and \(\vec \xi _\infty \). Equations (3.4)–(3.6) remain valid for \(s_k\) replaced by any sequence \(t_k\) converging to zero and satisfying \(t_k \geqslant s_k\), for all \(k \in {\mathbb {N}}\).

Moreover, for any sequence \(s_1,s_2, \ldots \) of positive numbers converging to zero, there exists a sequence \(t_k \geqslant s_k\) converging to zero such that

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H_{\infty }^2\,\mathrm{d}\mu _\infty \leqslant \liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty }\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2{\setminus } \bigcup _{i=1}^NB_{t_k}(b_i)} H_{k}^2\,\mathrm{d}\mu _k. \end{aligned}$$

(3.7)

Proof

Suppose U is an open subset of \({\mathbb {S}}^2 {\setminus } \{b_1, \ldots , b_N\}\), K is a compact subset of U, and \(x: U \rightarrow {\mathbb {R}}^2\) is a conformal chart for \({\mathbb {S}}^2\). Denote by

$$\begin{aligned} \lambda _k = \log |\partial _{x^1} \vec \xi _k|, \qquad \lambda _\infty = \log |\partial _{x^1} \vec \xi _\infty | \end{aligned}$$

the conformal factors. Notice that the volume element corresponding to \(\vec \xi _k\) is given by \(e^{2\lambda _k}\). In a first step we will show that

$$\begin{aligned}&e^{2\lambda _k} \rightarrow e^{2\lambda _\infty } \qquad \text {as } k \rightarrow \infty \text { in }L^p(x[K]), \end{aligned}$$

(3.8)

$$\begin{aligned}&\vec n_k \cdot \vec \xi _k e^{2\lambda _k} \rightarrow \vec n_ \infty \cdot \vec \xi _ \infty e^{2\lambda _\infty } \qquad \text {as } k \rightarrow \infty \text { in }L^p(x[K]) \end{aligned}$$

(3.9)

for any \(1 \leqslant p < \infty \), as well as

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{K} H_{\infty }\,\mathrm{d}\mu _\infty&= \lim _{k\rightarrow \infty }\int \nolimits _{K}H_{k}\,\mathrm{d}\mu _k, \end{aligned}$$

(3.10)

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{K} H_{\infty }^2\,\mathrm{d}\mu _\infty&\leqslant \liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty }\int \nolimits _{K}H_{k}^2\,\mathrm{d}\mu _k. \end{aligned}$$

(3.11)

A simple argument by contradiction shows that it is enough to prove the statement after passing to a subsequence of k. Since the \(\vec \xi _k\)’s and \(\vec \xi _\infty \) are conformal and x is a conformal chart, we can write the mean curvature vector as

$$\begin{aligned} 2\vec {H}_{k} = e^{-2\lambda _k}\Delta \vec \xi _k, \qquad 2\vec {H}_{\infty } = e^{-2\lambda _\infty }\Delta \vec \xi _\infty , \end{aligned}$$

where \(\Delta \) is the flat Laplacian with respect to x. By Hypothesis (3.3), we have that

$$\begin{aligned} \vec {H}_{k} e^{2\lambda _k} = \frac{1}{2}\Delta \vec \xi _k \rightharpoonup \frac{1}{2}\Delta \vec \xi _\infty = \vec {H}_{\infty } e^{2\lambda _\infty } \end{aligned}$$

as \(k \rightarrow \infty \) weakly in \(L^2(x[K],{\mathbb {R}}^3)\), which implies (3.10).

By the Rellich–Kondrachov Compactness Theorem, after passing to a subsequence, there holds

$$\begin{aligned} \partial _{x^1} \vec \xi _k \rightarrow \partial _{x^1} \vec \xi _\infty \qquad \text {as } k\rightarrow \infty \text { in } L^p_{\mathrm {loc}}(x[U],{\mathbb {R}}^3) \end{aligned}$$

(3.12)

for any \(1 \leqslant p < \infty \). Therefore, using Hypothesis (3.2) and passing to a further subsequence, it follows that

$$\begin{aligned} e^{-\lambda _k} = |\partial _{x^1} \vec \xi _k|^{-1} \rightarrow |\partial _{x^1} \vec \xi _\infty |^{-1} = e^{-\lambda _\infty } \qquad \text {as }k\rightarrow \infty \text { in }L^2(x[K]). \end{aligned}$$

It follows that

$$\begin{aligned} \vec {H}_{k}\sqrt{e^{2\lambda _k}} = \frac{1}{2}e^{-\lambda _k}\Delta \vec \xi _k \rightharpoonup \frac{1}{2}e^{-\lambda _\infty }\Delta \vec \xi _\infty = \vec {H}_{\infty }\sqrt{e^{2\lambda _k}}, \end{aligned}$$

as \(k\rightarrow \infty \) weakly in \(L^2(x[K], {\mathbb {R}}^3)\), which implies (3.11) by lower semi-continuity of the \(L^2\)-norm under weak convergence.

Similarly, from Hypothesis (3.2) and the strong convergence (3.12), we infer (3.8).

Again by the strong convergence (3.12) and Hypothesis (3.2), we can extract a subsequence such that by dominated convergence,

$$\begin{aligned} \vec n_k = e^{-2\lambda _k} (\partial _{x^1} \vec \xi _k \times \partial _{x^2} \vec \xi _k) \rightarrow e^{-2\lambda _\infty } (\partial _{x^1} \vec \xi _\infty \times \partial _{x^2} \vec \xi _\infty ) = \vec n_\infty \end{aligned}$$

as \(k \rightarrow \infty \) in \( L^p(x[K], {\mathbb {R}}^3)\) for any \(1\leqslant p < \infty \). Using this and the fact that by the Rellich–Kondrachov Compactness Theorem

$$\begin{aligned} \vec \xi _k \rightarrow \vec \xi _\infty \qquad \text {as } k \rightarrow \infty \text { in } L^p(x[K], {\mathbb {R}}^3) \end{aligned}$$

for any \(1 \leqslant p < \infty \), one verifies (3.9).

Next, let \(r_k\) be any sequence of positive numbers converging to zero and abbreviate

$$\begin{aligned} f_k = e^{2\lambda _k}, \qquad f_\infty = e^{2\lambda _\infty }, \qquad K_{r_k} ={\mathbb {S}}^2 {\setminus } \bigcup _{i=1}^NB_{r_k}(b_i). \end{aligned}$$

First, notice that for any Borel function f on \({\mathbb {S}}^2\) with \(\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2}|f|\,\mathrm{d}\mu _\infty < \infty \), it holds that

$$\begin{aligned} \lim _{k\rightarrow \infty } \int \nolimits _{K_{r_k}}f \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\infty } = \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} f \,\mathrm{d}\mu _{\infty }, \end{aligned}$$

(3.13)

which is a consequence of the dominated convergence theorem and the fact that finite sets have \(\mu _\infty \) measure zero. Let \(n_0 = 1\). For each positive integer j, we use (3.8) to inductively choose \(n_j > n_{j-1}\) such that

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{x[K_{r_j}]}|f_k - f_\infty |\,d{\mathscr {L}}^2 \leqslant \frac{1}{j} \qquad \text {for all } k\geqslant n_j. \end{aligned}$$

Moreover, define \(l_k = j\) for all integers k with \(n_{j-1}< k \leqslant n_j\) and define \(s_k = r_{l_k}\). Then, we have that \(s_k \rightarrow 0\) as \(k \rightarrow \infty \) as well as

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{x[K_{s_k}]} |f_k - f_\infty | \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 \rightarrow 0 \qquad \text {as } k \rightarrow \infty , \end{aligned}$$

(3.14)

which in particular remains valid for \(s_k\) replaced by any \(t_k \geqslant s_k\). Hence, by (3.13) we can deduce (3.4). Using the convergence on compact sets (3.9)–(3.11), Equations (3.5)–(3.7) follow similarly. It only remains to show that Equation (3.5) is still valid after replacing \(s_k\) by any sequence \(t_k \geqslant s_k\) converging to zero. Hence, we only have to show that

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{K_{s_k} {\setminus } K_{t_k}} H_k \, \mathrm{d}\mu _k \rightarrow 0 \qquad \text {as } k \rightarrow \infty . \end{aligned}$$

This follows because, by Hölder’s inequality,

$$\begin{aligned} \Bigl | \int \nolimits _{K_{s_k} {\setminus } K_{t_k}} H_k \, \mathrm{d}\mu _k \Bigr | \leqslant \Bigl (\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H_k^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _k \Bigr )^{1/2} \Bigl (\int \nolimits _{K_{s_k} {\setminus } K_{t_k}} 1 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _k \Bigr )^{1/2}. \end{aligned}$$

The first factor on the right hand side is bounded by (3.1). To see that the second factor goes to zero as k tends to infinity, we apply (3.14) and the fact that \(\mu _{\infty }(\bigcup _{i = 1}^NB_{t_k}(b_i)) \rightarrow 0\) as \(k \rightarrow \infty \). \(\quad \square \)

Next we will define the notion of a bubble tree. The idea is that the different bubbles can be parametrised by decomposing a single 2-sphere. The bubbles can then be attached to each other by a Lipschitz map, see (3.15) and (3.16).

Definition 3.2

(Bubble tree of weak immersions, see [28, Definition 7.1]) An \(N+1\) tuple \(\vec T = (\vec f, \vec \Phi ^1, \ldots , \vec \Phi ^N)\) is called a bubble tree of weak immersions if and only if N is a positive integer, \(\vec f \in W^{1, \infty }({\mathbb {S}}^2, {\mathbb {R}}^3)\), and \(\vec \Phi ^1, \ldots , \vec \Phi ^N \in {\mathcal {F}}_{{\mathbb {S}}^2}\) are weak branched conformal immersions with finite total curvature such that the following holds:

There exist open geodesic balls \(B^1, \ldots , B^N \subset {\mathbb {S}}^2\) such that

\(\overline{B^1} = {\mathbb {S}}^2\) and for all \(i \ne i'\) either \(\overline{B^i} \subset B^{i'}\) or \(\overline{B^{i'}} \subset B^i\).

For all \(i \in \{1, \ldots , N\}\) there exists a positive integer \(N^i\) and disjoint open geodesic balls \(B^{i,1}, \ldots , B^{i,N^i} \subset {\mathbb {S}}^2\) whose closures are included in \(B^i\) such that

for all \(i' \ne i\) either \(\overline{B^i} \subset B^{i'}\) or \(\overline{B^{i'}} \subset B^{i,j}\) for some \(j \in \{1, \ldots , N^i\}\).

For all \(i \in \{1, \ldots , N\}\) there exist distinct points \(b^{i,1}, \ldots , b^{i,N^i} \in {\mathbb {S}}^2\) and a Lipschitz diffeomorphism

$$\begin{aligned} \Xi ^i: B^i {\setminus } \bigcup _{j = 1}^{N^i - 1} \overline{B^{i,j}} \rightarrow {\mathbb {S}}^2 {\setminus } \{b^{i,1}, \ldots , b^{i, N^i}\}, \end{aligned}$$

which extends to a Lipschitz map

$$\begin{aligned} {\overline{\Xi }}_i: \overline{B^i} {\setminus } \bigcup _{j=1}^{N^i - 1}B^{i,j} \rightarrow {\mathbb {S}}^2 \end{aligned}$$

such that

$$\begin{aligned} \overline{\Xi }_i[\partial B^{i,j}] = b^{i,j} \text { whenever } j \in \{1, \ldots , N^{i}-1\}, \qquad {\overline{\Xi }}_i[\partial B^i] = b^{i,N^i}. \end{aligned}$$

Moreover, for all \(i \in \{1, \ldots , N\}\),

$$\begin{aligned} \vec f(x) = (\vec \Phi ^i \circ \Xi ^i)(x) \qquad \text {whenever } x \in B^i {\setminus } \bigcup _{j = 1}^{N^{i}-1} \overline{B^{i,j}}, \end{aligned}$$

(3.15)

and for all \(j \in \{1, \ldots , N^i\}\) there exists \(p^{i,j} \in {\mathbb {R}}^3\) such that

$$\begin{aligned} \vec f(x) = p^{i,j} \qquad \text {whenever } x \in B^{i,j} {\setminus } \bigcup _{i' \in J^{i,j}} \overline{B^{i'}} \end{aligned}$$

(3.16)

where \(J^{i,j} = \{i': \overline{B^{i'}} \subset B^{i,j}\}\).

Finally, we define

$$\begin{aligned} {\mathcal {W}}(\vec T):= & {} \sum _{i = 1}^N \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H_{\vec \Phi ^i}^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi ^i}, \qquad {{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}(\vec T) := \sum _{i = 1}^N \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} 1 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi ^i}, \\ {{\,\mathrm{Vol}\,}}(\vec T):= & {} \sum _{i = 1}^N \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} \vec n_{\vec \Phi ^i} \cdot \vec \Phi ^i \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi ^i}. \end{aligned}$$

The next theorem establishes the weak closure of bubble trees, as well as the convergence of the constraints in the Helfrich problem and the lower semi-continuity of the Willmore energy. The proof builds on [28].

Theorem 3.3

(Weak closure and lower semi-continuity of bubble trees) Suppose \(\vec T_k = (\vec f_k, \vec \Phi ^1_k, \ldots , \vec \Phi ^{N_k}_k)\) is a sequence of bubble trees of weak immersions and

$$\begin{aligned} \limsup _{k \rightarrow \infty } \sum _{i = 1}^{N_k} \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 } 1 + |\mathrm{d}\vec n_{\vec \Phi _k^i}|^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _k^i} < \infty , \qquad \liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty } \sum _{i = 1}^{N_k} {{\,\mathrm{diam}\,}}\vec \Phi _k^i[{\mathbb {S}}^2] > 0.\nonumber \\ \end{aligned}$$

(3.17)

Then, there exists a subsequence of \(\vec T_k\) which we again denote by \(\vec T_k\) such that \(N_k = N\) for some positive integer N and there exists a sequence of diffeomorphisms \(\Psi _k\) of \({\mathbb {S}}^2\) such that

$$\begin{aligned}&\vec f_k \circ \Psi _k \rightarrow \vec u_\infty \qquad \text { as } k \rightarrow \infty \text { uniformly in } C^0({\mathbb {S}}^2, {\mathbb {R}}^3), \\&{{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}\vec f_k[{\mathbb {S}}^2] \rightarrow {{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}\vec u_\infty [{\mathbb {S}}^2] \qquad \text {as } k \rightarrow \infty \end{aligned}$$

for some \(\vec u_\infty \in W^{1, \infty }({\mathbb {S}}^2, {\mathbb {R}}^3)\). Moreover, for all \(i \in \{1,\ldots , N\}\) there exists a positive integer \(Q^i\) and sequences \(f_k^{i,1}, \ldots , f_k^{i,Q^i}\) of positive conformal diffeomorphisms of \({\mathbb {S}}^2\) such that for each \(j \in \{1, \ldots , Q^i\}\) there exist finitely many points \(b^{i,j,1}, \ldots b^{i,j,Q^{i,j}} \in {\mathbb {S}}^2\) with

$$\begin{aligned} \vec \Phi ^i_k \circ f_k^{i,j} \rightharpoonup \vec \xi ^{i,j}_\infty \qquad \text { as } k \rightarrow \infty \text { weakly in } W_{\mathrm {loc}}^{2,2}({\mathbb {S}}^2 {\setminus } \{b^{i,j,1}, \ldots b^{i,j,Q^{i,j}}\}, {\mathbb {R}}^3)\nonumber \\ \end{aligned}$$

(3.18)

for some branched Lipschitz conformal immersion \(\vec \xi _\infty ^{i,j} \in {\mathcal {F}}_{{\mathbb {S}}^2}\). Furthermore,

$$\begin{aligned} \vec T_\infty := \bigl (\vec u_\infty ,(\vec \xi ^{1,j}_\infty )_{j = 1, \ldots , Q^1}, \ldots , (\vec \xi _\infty ^{N,j})_{j = 1, \ldots , Q^N}\bigr ) \end{aligned}$$

is a bubble tree of weak immersions and

$$\begin{aligned}&{\mathcal {W}}(\vec T_\infty ) \leqslant \liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty } {\mathcal {W}} (\vec T_k), \quad {{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}(\vec T_\infty ) = \lim _{k\rightarrow \infty } {{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}(\vec T_k), \\&{{\,\mathrm{Vol}\,}}(\vec T_\infty ) = \lim _{k\rightarrow \infty } {{\,\mathrm{Vol}\,}}(\vec T_k) \end{aligned}$$

as well as

$$\begin{aligned} \sum _{i = 1}^{N} \sum _{j = 1}^{Q^i} \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 } H_{\vec \xi _\infty ^{i,j}} \, \mathrm{d} \mu _{\vec \xi _\infty ^{i,j}} = \lim _{k\rightarrow \infty } \sum _{i = 1}^N \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 } H_{\vec \Phi _k^i} \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _k^i}. \end{aligned}$$

Proof

We first consider the special case where \(N_k = 1\) for all positive integers k. By [28, Theorem 1.5], it then only remains to show the convergence properties of the Willmore energy \({\mathcal {W}}\), the volume, and the integral of the mean curvature. In view of Lemma 3.1, we can add Equations (3.5)–(3.7) for \(\vec \xi _k\) replaced by \(\vec \Phi _k \circ f_k^i\) to the conclusion of the Domain Decomposition Lemma [28, Theorem 6.1]. Therefore, adapting the proof of [28, Theorem 1.5], we get that after passing to a subsequence and denoting \(\vec \Phi _k := \vec \Phi _k^1\), there exists a positive integer N, sequences \(f_k^1, \ldots , f_k^N\) of positive conformal diffeomorphisms of \({\mathbb {S}}^2\), and for each \(i \in \{1, \ldots , N\}\) there exist points \(b^{i,1}, \ldots , b^{i,N^i} \in {\mathbb {S}}^2\) such that (3.18) and (1.5) hold. Moreover, there exists a sequence of positive numbers \(s_k\) converging to zero such that for \(i = 1, \ldots , N\) Equations (3.4)–(3.7) are satisfied for \(\vec \xi _k\) replaced by \(\vec \Phi _k \circ f^i_k\). Furthermore, defining

$$\begin{aligned} S^i_k := {\mathbb {S}}^2 {\setminus } \bigcup _{j=1}^{N^i} B_{s_k}(b^{i,j}), \end{aligned}$$

and for \(j = 1, \ldots , N^i\) the sets of indices

$$\begin{aligned} J^{i,j} := \{i': \forall k \in {\mathbb {N}}: \bigl ((f_k^i)^{-1} \circ f_k^{i'}\bigr )[S_k^{i'}]\subset B_{s_k}(b^{i,j})\}, \end{aligned}$$

and

$$\begin{aligned} {\hat{J}}^{i,j}:= \{i' \in J^{i,j}: \forall k \in {\mathbb {N}}: \not \exists i'':\bigl ((f_k^i)^{-1} \circ f_k^{i'}\bigr )[S_k^{i'}]\subset {{\,\mathrm{Conv}\,}}\bigl ((f_k^i)^{-1} \circ f_k^{i''}\bigr )[S_k^{i''}]\}, \end{aligned}$$

and the necks

$$\begin{aligned} S_k^{i,j} := B_{s_k}(b^{i,j}) {\setminus } \bigcup _{i' \in {{\hat{J}}}^{i,j}}\bigl ((f^i_k)^{-1} \circ f^{i'}_k\bigr )\bigl [{\mathbb {S}}^2 {\setminus } B_{s_k}(b^{i',N^{i'}})\bigr ], \end{aligned}$$

it holds that

$$\begin{aligned} \lim _{k\rightarrow \infty } \int \nolimits _{S_k^{i,j}} 1 \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _k \circ f^i_k} = 0, \qquad \lim _{k\rightarrow \infty } {{\,\mathrm{diam}\,}}(\vec \Phi _k \circ f^i_k)[S^{i,j}_k] = 0. \end{aligned}$$

(3.19)

Finally, for any \(\mu _{\vec \Phi _k}\) integrable Borel function \(\varphi \) on \({\mathbb {S}}^2\), we get

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{ {\mathbb {S}}^2 } \varphi \, \mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _k}= & {} \sum _{i = 1}^N \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2{\setminus }\bigcup _{j=1}^{N_i}B_{s_k}(b^{i,j})}\varphi \circ f^i_k\,\mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _k\circ f^i_k}\nonumber \\&+ \sum _{i = 1}^N\sum _{j = 1}^{N^i-1}\int \nolimits _{S_k^{i,j}}\varphi \circ f^i_k\,\mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _k\circ f^i_k}. \end{aligned}$$

(3.20)

We notice that by the strong convergence (1.5),

$$\begin{aligned} \sup _{k \in {\mathbb {N}}} \sup _{S_k^{i,j}}|\vec \Phi _k \circ f^i_k| \leqslant C < \infty \end{aligned}$$

for some finite number \(C > 0\). Hence, by Hölder’s inequality,

$$\begin{aligned}&\Bigl |\int \nolimits _{S_k^{i,j}}H_{\vec \Phi _k\circ f^i_k}\,\mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _k\circ f^i_k}\Bigr | \leqslant \Bigl (\int \nolimits _{S_k^{i,j}}1\,\mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _k\circ f^i_k}\Bigr )^{1/2}\Bigl (\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2}H_{\vec \Phi _k \circ f_k^i}^2\,\mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _k \circ f_k^i}\Bigr )^{1/2}, \\&\Bigl |\int \nolimits _{S_k^{i,j}}\vec n_{\vec \Phi _k\circ f^i_k} \cdot (\vec \Phi _k\circ f^i_k)\,\mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _k\circ f^i_k}\Bigr | \leqslant \Bigl ( \int \nolimits _{S_k^{i,j}}1\,\mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _k\circ f^i_k} \Bigr )^{1/2} \Bigl (\int \nolimits _{S_k^{i,j}}C^2\,\mathrm{d}\mu _{\vec \Phi _k\circ f^i_k} \Bigr )^{1/2}. \end{aligned}$$

By (3.17) and (3.19), the right hand side of each line goes to zero as k tends to infinity. That means the last term of Equation (3.20) goes to zero as k tends to infinity when \(\varphi \) is replaced by \(H_{\vec \Phi _k}\) as well as when \(\varphi \) is replaced by \(\vec n_{\vec \Phi _k} \cdot \vec \Phi _k\). Therefore, using (3.5) and (3.6), we can conclude the convergence of the integrated mean curvature and the convergence of the volume from (3.20). Similarly, we can conclude the lower semi-continuity of the Willmore energy \({\mathcal {W}}\) from (3.20) by replacing \(\varphi \) with \(H_{\vec \Phi _k}^2\), using super linearity of the limit inferior and by ignoring the non-negative second term in (3.20).

Now, the general case follows analogously to the proof of [28, Theorem 7.2].

\(\square \)

Throughout this section, \(\Sigma \) denotes a smooth, oriented, and closed 2-dimensional manifold. Moreover, \(c_0\), \(\alpha \), and \(\rho \) are the parameters of the Canham–Helfrich energy, that is \(c_0 \in {\mathbb {R}}\) and \(\alpha , \rho \geqslant 0\), see (2.14). A (possibly branched) weak immersion \(\vec \Phi \in {\mathcal {F}}_\Sigma \) with branch points \(\{b_{1}, \ldots , b_{N}\}\) is called weak Canham–Helfrich immersion if

$$\begin{aligned} \left. \frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\right| _{t = 0} {\mathcal {H}}^{c_0}_{\alpha ,\rho }(\vec \Phi + t\vec \omega ) = 0 \end{aligned}$$

(4.1)

for all \(\vec \omega \in C_{c}^\infty (\Sigma {\setminus } \{b_{1}, \ldots , b_{N}\}, {\mathbb {R}}^3)\).

In what follows, we will first compute the Canham–Helfrich equation in divergence form, see Lemma 4.1. Then, we will prove that a weak immersion satisfying the Canham–Helfrich equation is smooth away from its branch points, see Theorem 4.3. The proof is based on the regularity theory for weak Willmore immersions developed by Rivière [32, 34]. An important step in Riviere’s regularity theory is the discovery of hidden conservation laws for weak Willmore immersions. In the framework of Canham–Helfich immersions, the corresponding hidden conservation laws were discovered by Bernard [4].

Lemma 4.1

(Canham–Helfrich Euler–Lagrange equation in divergence form) Suppose \(\vec \Phi \in {\mathcal {F}}_\Sigma \) is a weak Canham–Helfrich immersion with branch points \(\{b_1, \ldots , b_N\}\). Then, away from its branch points, that is in conformal parametrisations from the open unit disk \(D^2\) into a subset of \(\Sigma {\setminus } \bigcup _{i = 1}^N B_\varepsilon (b_i)\) for any \(\varepsilon > 0\), it holds that

$$\begin{aligned} \vec {{\mathcal {W}}} = -{{\,\mathrm{div}\,}}\left[ c_0 \nabla \vec n + (2c_0H - c_0^2 - \alpha ) \nabla \vec \Phi - \frac{\rho }{2} \vec \Phi \times \nabla ^\bot \vec \Phi \right] \end{aligned}$$

(4.2)

in \({\mathcal {D}}'(D^2, {\mathbb {R}}^3)\), where

$$\begin{aligned} \vec {{\mathcal {W}}} := {{\,\mathrm{div}\,}}\frac{1}{2}\left[ 2\nabla \vec H - 3H\nabla \vec n + \vec H \times \nabla ^\bot \vec n\right] \end{aligned}$$

(4.3)

corresponds to the first variation of the Willmore energy.

Proof

After composing with a conformal chart away from the branch points, we may assume that \(\vec \Phi \) is a map \(D^2 \rightarrow {\mathbb {R}}^3\). Let \(\vec \omega \in C^\infty _{c}(D, {\mathbb {R}}^3)\) and define \(\vec \Phi _t := \vec \Phi + t\vec \omega \) for \(t \in {\mathbb {R}}\). The conformal factor \(\lambda \) is given by \(2e^{2\lambda } = |\nabla \vec \Phi |^2\) and the metric coefficients \((g_t)_{ij}\) by \((g_t)_{ij} = \partial _i \vec \Phi _t \cdot \partial _j \vec \Phi _t\). Standard computations (see for instance [34, (7.8)–(7.10)]) give

$$\begin{aligned}&\Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0} (g_t)^{ij} = - e^{-4\lambda }(\partial _i \vec \omega \cdot \partial _j \vec \Phi + \partial _i \vec \Phi \cdot \partial _j \vec \omega ) \\&g^{ij} \Bigl (\partial _i \Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0} \vec n_t \cdot \partial _j \vec \Phi \Bigr ) = -e^{-2\lambda }\bigl (\partial _1(\partial _1 \vec \omega \cdot \vec n) + \partial _2(\partial _2 \vec \omega \cdot \vec n)\bigr ) \\&\Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0}\sqrt{\det (g_t)_{ij}} = \partial _1 \vec \Phi \cdot \partial _1 \vec \omega + \partial _2 \vec \Phi \cdot \partial _2 \vec \omega . \end{aligned}$$

Therefore, using

$$\begin{aligned} \Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0} H_t&= - \Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0} \frac{1}{2} (g_t)^{ij} \Bigl (\partial _i \vec n_t \cdot \partial _j \vec \Phi _t \Bigr )\\&= -\frac{1}{2} \Bigl (\Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0} (g_t)^{ij} \Bigr ) \partial _i \vec n \cdot \partial _j \vec \Phi - g^{ij}\frac{1}{2}\Bigl (\partial _i \Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0} \vec n_t \cdot \partial _j \vec \Phi + \partial _i \vec n \cdot \partial _j \vec \omega \Bigr ), \end{aligned}$$

we obtain

$$\begin{aligned} \Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0} \int \nolimits _{D^2} H_t \, \mathrm{d}\mu _t =&\int \nolimits _{D^2} \Bigl (\Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0} H_t \Bigr ) \sqrt{\det g_{ij}} + H \Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0}\sqrt{\det (g_t)_{ij}} \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 \nonumber \\ =&\int \nolimits _{D^2} \frac{1}{2} e^{-2\lambda }\sum _{i,j = 1}^2(\partial _i \vec \omega \cdot \partial _j \vec \Phi + \partial _i \vec \Phi \cdot \partial _j \vec \omega ) (\partial _{i} \vec n \cdot \partial _j \vec \Phi ) \nonumber \\&+ \frac{1}{2}\big (\partial _1(\partial _1 \vec \omega \cdot \vec n) + \partial _2 (\partial _2 \vec \omega \cdot \vec n) \bigr ) - \frac{1}{2} g^{ij} \partial _i \vec n \cdot \partial _j \vec \omega e^{2\lambda } \nonumber \\&+ H\bigl ( \partial _1 \vec \Phi \cdot \partial _1 \vec \omega + \partial _2 \vec \Phi \cdot \partial _2 \vec \omega \bigr )\, d{\mathscr {L}}^2. \end{aligned}$$

(4.4)

Using that \(\vec \omega \) has compact support in \(D^2\),

$$\begin{aligned} g^{ij} \partial _i \vec n \cdot \partial _j \vec \omega e^{2\lambda } = e^{-2\lambda } \sum _{i,j = 1}^2 (\partial _i \vec n \cdot \partial _j \vec \Phi )(\partial _j \vec \Phi \cdot \partial _i \vec \omega ), \end{aligned}$$

and using the symmetry of the second fundamental form, that is \(\partial _i \vec n \cdot \partial _j \vec \Phi = \partial _j \vec n \cdot \partial _i \vec \Phi \), we compute further that

$$\begin{aligned} \Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0} \int \nolimits _{D^2} H_t \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _t&= \int \nolimits _{D^2} -\frac{1}{2} \vec \omega \cdot \partial _1 \Bigl [e^{-2\lambda }\bigl ((\partial _1 \vec n \cdot \partial _1 \vec \Phi ) \partial _1 \vec \Phi + (\partial _1 \vec n \cdot \partial _2 \vec \Phi ) \partial _2 \vec \Phi )\bigr )\Bigr ] \nonumber \\&\qquad - \frac{1}{2} \vec \omega \cdot \partial _2 \Bigl [ e^{-2\lambda }\bigl ((\partial _2 \vec n \cdot \partial _1 \vec \Phi ) \partial _1 \vec \Phi + (\partial _2 \vec n \cdot \partial _2 \vec \Phi ) \partial _2 \vec \Phi )\bigr ) \Bigr ]\nonumber \\&\qquad - \vec \omega \cdot \bigl (\partial _1(H \partial _1 \vec \Phi ) + \partial _2(H \partial _2 \vec \Phi )\bigr ) \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 \nonumber \\&\quad = - \int \nolimits _{D^2} \vec \omega \cdot \partial _1 \left( \frac{1}{2} \pi _T(\partial _1 \vec n) + H \partial _1 \vec \Phi \right) \nonumber \\&\qquad + \vec \omega \cdot \partial _2 \left( \frac{1}{2}\pi _T(\partial _2 \vec n) + H \partial _2 \vec \Phi \right) \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2, \end{aligned}$$

(4.5)

which gives

$$\begin{aligned} \Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0} \int \nolimits _{D^2} H_t \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _t = -\int \nolimits _{D^2} \vec \omega \cdot {{\,\mathrm{div}\,}}\left[ \frac{1}{2}\nabla \vec n + H \nabla \vec \Phi \right] \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2. \end{aligned}$$

(4.6)

From [34, Corollary 7.3] we know that

$$\begin{aligned} \Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0} \int \nolimits _{D^2} H_t^2 \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _t = \int \nolimits _{D^2} \vec \omega \cdot {{\,\mathrm{div}\,}}\frac{1}{2}\left[ 2\nabla \vec H - 3H\nabla \vec n + \vec H \times \nabla ^\bot \vec n\right] \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2;\nonumber \\ \end{aligned}$$

(4.7)

see also [32]. Moreover (see for instance [4, Chapter 3.3]),

$$\begin{aligned} \Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0} \int \nolimits _{D^2} 1 \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _t = - \int \nolimits _{D^2} \vec \omega \cdot {{\,\mathrm{div}\,}}\nabla \vec \Phi \, d {\mathscr {L}}^2 \end{aligned}$$

(4.8)

and

$$\begin{aligned} \Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0} \int \nolimits _{D^2} \vec n_t \cdot \vec \Phi _t \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _t = - \int \nolimits _{D^2} \vec \omega \cdot {{\,\mathrm{div}\,}}\left[ \frac{1}{2} \vec \Phi \times \nabla ^\bot \vec \Phi \right] \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2. \end{aligned}$$

(4.9)

Putting (4.6) – (4.9) into (4.1) yields (4.2). \(\quad \square \)

Remark 4.2

Usually in the literature (see for instance [4, Chapter 3.3]) one finds the expression of the first variation for \(\int H {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{g}\) written as

$$\begin{aligned} \Bigl .\frac{d}{{\mathrm{d}}t}\Bigr |_{t = 0} \int \nolimits _{D^2} H_t \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _t = \int \nolimits _{D^2} (\vec \omega \cdot \vec n) \left( \frac{1}{2} {{\mathbb {I}}}^{i}_{j} {{\mathbb {I}}}^{j}_{i}-2H^{2} \right) {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{g}. \end{aligned}$$

(4.10)

It is not hard to check the equivalence of (4.10) with (4.6) proved above. The advantage of the expression (4.6) is twofold: first it invokes less regularity of the immersion map \(\vec \Phi \), second it is already in divergence form. Both advantages will be useful in establishing the regularity of weak Canham–Helfrich immersions: indeed, (4.10) would correspond to an \(L^{1}\) term in the Euler–Lagrange equation (which is typically a problematic right hand side for elliptic regularity theory) while (4.6) corresponds to the divergence of an \(L^{2}\) term (which is a much better right hand side in elliptic regularity).

Theorem 4.3

(Smoothness of weak Canham–Helfrich immersions) Suppose \(\vec \Phi \in {\mathcal {F}}_\Sigma \) is a weak Canham–Helfrich immersion. Then \(\vec \Phi \) is a \(C^\infty \) immersion away from the branch points.

Proof

After composing with a conformal chart of \(\Sigma \) away from the branch points onto the unit disk \(D^2\), we may assume that \(\vec \Phi \) is a map \(D^2 \rightarrow {\mathbb {R}}^3\) without branch points and \(\vec \Phi \) satisfies the Canham–Helfrich equation (4.2). It is enough to show that \(\vec \Phi \in C^\infty (B_{1/2}(0))\). The proof splits into three parts.

Step 1: Conservation laws. In view of the Canham–Helfrich equation (4.2), we define \(\vec T \in L^2(D^2, ({\mathbb {R}}^3)^2)\) by letting

$$\begin{aligned} \vec T : = c_0 \nabla \vec n + (2c_0H - c_0^2 - \alpha ) \nabla \vec \Phi - \frac{\rho }{2} \vec \Phi \times \nabla ^\bot \vec \Phi .^{1} \end{aligned}$$

Footnote 1Then, \({{\,\mathrm{div}\,}}\vec T = - \vec {{\mathcal {W}}}\) where \(\vec {{\mathcal {W}}}\) is as in (4.3). Hence \(\vec {{\mathcal {W}}} \in H^{-1}(D^2, {\mathbb {R}}^3)\) and there exists a solution \(\vec V\) of

$$\begin{aligned} {\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} \Delta \vec V = - \,\vec {{\mathcal {W}}} \\ \vec V \in H^1_0(D^2, {\mathbb {R}}^3). \end{array}\right. } \end{aligned}$$

Therefore, we can find

$$\begin{aligned} \vec X \in W^{2,2}(D^2,{\mathbb {R}}^3), \qquad Y \in W^{2,2}(D^2, {\mathbb {R}}), \end{aligned}$$

(4.11)

such that

$$\begin{aligned} \left\{ \begin{array}{llll} \Delta \vec X &{} = \nabla \vec V \times \nabla \vec \Phi &{}&{} \quad \text {in } D^2 \\ \vec X &{} = 0 &{}&{} \quad \text {on } \partial D^2\\ \end{array}\right. \end{aligned}$$

and

$$\begin{aligned} \left\{ \begin{array}{llll} \Delta Y &{} = \nabla \vec V \cdot \nabla \vec \Phi &{}&{}\quad \text {in } D^2 \\ Y &{} = 0 &{}&{} \quad \text {on } \partial D^2. \end{array}\right. \end{aligned}$$

After the breakthrough of Rivière [32], Bernard [4, Chapter 2.2] showed that by invariance of the Willmore functional under conformal transformation and the weak Poincaré Lemma, one can find potentials \(\vec L, \vec R \in W^{1, 2}(D^2, {\mathbb {R}}^3)\), and \(S \in W^{1,2}(D^2, {\mathbb {R}})\) such that

$$\begin{aligned} \left\{ \begin{aligned} \nabla ^\bot \vec L&= \vec T - \nabla \vec V \\ \nabla ^\bot \vec R&= \vec L \times \nabla ^\bot \vec \Phi - \vec H \times \nabla \vec \Phi - \nabla \vec X \\ \nabla ^\bot S&= \langle \vec L, \nabla ^\bot \vec \Phi \rangle - \nabla Y. \end{aligned} \right. \end{aligned}$$

Indeed, from [4, Chapter 3.3], we find that \(\vec R, S, \vec X, Y\), and \(\vec \Phi \) satisfy the following system of conservation laws:

$$\begin{aligned} \Delta \vec R&= \langle \nabla ^\bot \vec n, \nabla S \rangle + \nabla ^\bot \vec n \times \nabla \vec R + {{\,\mathrm{div}\,}}\Bigl [\langle \vec n, \nabla Y\rangle + \frac{\rho }{4}|\vec \Phi |^2 \nabla \vec \Phi \Bigr ] \end{aligned}$$

(4.12)

$$\begin{aligned} \Delta S&= \nabla ^\bot \vec n \cdot \nabla \vec R \end{aligned}$$

(4.13)

$$\begin{aligned} \Delta Y&= |\nabla \vec \Phi |^2\bigl (-(c_0^2 + \alpha ) +c_0H + \frac{\rho }{2} \vec \Phi \cdot \vec n \bigr ) \end{aligned}$$

(4.14)

$$\begin{aligned} \Delta \vec \Phi&= -\langle \nabla ^\bot S, \nabla \vec \Phi \rangle - \nabla ^\bot \vec R \times \nabla \vec \Phi + \langle \nabla \vec \Phi , \nabla Y \rangle + \frac{\rho }{4}|\vec \Phi |^2 |\nabla \vec \Phi |^2 \vec n. \end{aligned}$$

(4.15)

Step 2: Morrey decrease. We will show that for some number \(\alpha > 0\), it holds that

$$\begin{aligned} \sup _{r<1/4, \, a \in B_{1/2}(0)} r^{-\alpha } \int \nolimits _{B_r(a)} |\nabla \vec R|^2 + |\nabla S|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 < \infty . \end{aligned}$$

(4.16)

We let \(\varepsilon _0 > 0\) and fix its value later. Choose \(0< r_0 < 1/4\) such that

$$\begin{aligned} \sup _{a \in B_{1/2}(0)} \int \nolimits _{B_{r_0}(a)} |\nabla \vec n|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 < \varepsilon _0. \end{aligned}$$

(4.17)

Let a be any point in \(B_{1/2}(0)\). Denote by \(\vec R_0\) the solution of

$$\begin{aligned} \left\{ \begin{array}{llll} \Delta \vec R_0 &{} = {{\,\mathrm{div}\,}}\Bigl [\langle \vec n, \nabla Y\rangle + \frac{\rho }{4}|\vec \Phi |^2 \nabla \vec \Phi \Bigr ] &{}&{} \quad \text {in } D^2 \\ \vec R_0 &{} = 0 &{}&{} \quad \text {on } \partial D^2. \end{array}\right. \end{aligned}$$

Then, from (4.11) we obtain \(\vec R_0 \in W^{2,2}(B_1(0), {\mathbb {R}}^3)\) and hence \(\nabla \vec R_0 \in L^p(B_1(0), ({\mathbb {R}}^3)^2)\) for any \(1 \leqslant p < \infty \). Therefore, by Hölder’s inequality,

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{B_r(a)}|\nabla \vec R_0|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 \leqslant r \varvec{\alpha }(2)^{1/2}\Bigl (\int \nolimits _{B_1(0)} |\nabla \vec R_0|^4 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2\Bigl )^{1/2} =: r C_1 \end{aligned}$$

(4.18)

whenever \(0 < r \leqslant r_0\) where \(\varvec{\alpha }(2)\) is the area of the unit disk. Let \(0 < r \leqslant r_0\) and let \(\vec \Psi _{\vec R}\) and \(\Psi _S\) be the solutions of

$$\begin{aligned} \left\{ \begin{array}{llll} \Delta \vec \Psi _{\vec R} &{} = \langle \nabla ^\bot \vec n, \nabla S \rangle + \nabla ^\bot \vec n \times \nabla \vec R &{}&{} \quad \text {in } B_{r}(a) \\ \vec \Psi _{\vec R} &{} = 0 &{}&{} \quad \text {on } \partial B_{r}(a)\\ \end{array}\right. \end{aligned}$$

and

$$\begin{aligned} \left\{ \begin{array}{llll} \Delta \Psi _{S} &{} = \nabla ^\bot \vec n \cdot \nabla \vec R &{}&{} \text {in } B_{r}(a) \\ \Psi _{S} &{} = 0 &{}&{} \text {on } \partial B_{r}(a).\\ \end{array}\right. \end{aligned}$$

Then, the maps

$$\begin{aligned} \vec \nu _{\vec R} : = \vec R - \vec R_0 - \vec \Psi _{\vec R}, \quad \hbox {and} \quad \nu _{S} : = S - \Psi _S \end{aligned}$$

are harmonic and satisfy

$$\begin{aligned} \vec \nu _{\vec R} = \vec R - \vec R_0, \quad \vec \nu _{S} = S \qquad \text {on } \partial B_r(a). \end{aligned}$$

Therefore, by monotonicity (see for instance [34, Lemma 7.10]), the Dirichlet principle, and (4.18),

$$\begin{aligned} \begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{B_{r/3}(a)} |\nabla \vec \nu _{\vec R}|^2 + |\nabla \nu _{S}|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2&\leqslant \frac{1}{9} \int \nolimits _{B_{r}(a)} |\nabla (\vec R - \vec R_0)|^2 + |\nabla S|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 \\&\leqslant \frac{2}{9} \int \nolimits _{B_{r}(a)} |\nabla \vec R |^2 + |\nabla S|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 + \frac{2}{9}rC_1. \end{aligned} \end{aligned}$$

By Wente’s theorem (see for instance [34, Theorem 3.7]) and the definition of \(r_0\) (4.17) we find that

$$\begin{aligned} \begin{aligned}&\int \nolimits _{B_{r}(a)}|\nabla \vec \Psi _{\vec R}|^2 + |\nabla \Psi _S|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 \\&\quad \leqslant C_2\int \nolimits _{B_{r_0}(a)} |\nabla \vec n|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 \int \nolimits _{B_{r}(a)} |\nabla \vec R|^2 + |\nabla S|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 \\&\quad \leqslant C_2\varepsilon _0\int \nolimits _{B_{r}(a)} |\nabla \vec R|^2 + |\nabla S|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 \end{aligned} \end{aligned}$$

(4.20)

for some constant \(0< C_2 < \infty \) independent of \(r, r_0, \vec \Psi _{\vec R}, \Psi _{S}\). Using the inequalities (4.18)–(4.20), we compute that

$$\begin{aligned}&\int \nolimits _{B_{r/3}(a)} |\nabla \vec R|^2 + |\nabla S|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 \\&\quad \leqslant 3\int \nolimits _{B_{r/3}(a)}|\nabla \vec \Psi _{\vec R}|^2 + |\nabla \Psi _S|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 \\&\qquad + 3\int \nolimits _{B_{r/3}(a)} |\nabla \vec \nu _{\vec R}|^2 + |\nabla \nu _{S}|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 + 3\int \nolimits _{B_{r/3}(a)}|\nabla \vec R_0|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 \\&\quad \leqslant (3C_2\varepsilon _0 + 6/9) \int \nolimits _{B_{r}(a)} |\nabla \vec R|^2 + |\nabla S|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 + \frac{6}{9} r C_1 + r C_1. \end{aligned}$$

$$\begin{aligned} \int \nolimits _{B_{r/3}(a)} |\nabla \vec R|^2 + |\nabla S|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 \leqslant \frac{7}{9}\int \nolimits _{B_{r}(a)} |\nabla \vec R|^2 + |\nabla S|^2 \, d{\mathscr {L}}^2 + r 2C_1 \end{aligned}$$

for all \(0<r\leqslant r_0\). We next show, by induction, that

for all \(n \in {\mathbb {N}}\). Indeed, letting

$$\begin{aligned} \nabla \vec n \in L^p_{\mathrm {loc}}(B_{1/2}(0), ({\mathbb {R}}^3)^2) \end{aligned}$$

for some \(p>2\) given in the previous step. By Hölder’s inequality and (4.12), (4.13) we first get

where \(q^* := 2q/(2 - q) = 2p/(4 - p)\) satisfies \(q^* > 2q = p\) as \(p > 2\).

Since \(\nabla \vec R_{0} \in L_{\mathrm {loc}}^{q}(B_{1/2}(0))\) for all \(1 \leqslant q < \infty \), we infer

$$\begin{aligned} \nabla \vec R \in L_{\mathrm {loc}}^{q^*}(B_{1/2}(0), ({\mathbb {R}}^3)^2), \qquad \nabla S \in L_{\mathrm {loc}}^{q^*}(B_{1/2}(0), {\mathbb {R}}^2). \end{aligned}$$

Notice that \(q^*\) as above induces a recursively defined sequence of real numbers. Given a starting point \(q_0 > 1\), this sequence is unbounded as \(q^* > 2q\). Hence, we can repeat this procedure to obtain

$$\begin{aligned} \nabla \vec R \in L^q_{\mathrm {loc}}(B_{1/2}(0), ({\mathbb {R}}^3)^2), \quad \nabla S \in L^q_{\mathrm {loc}}(B_{1/2}(0), {\mathbb {R}}^2) \qquad \text {for all } 1 \leqslant q <\infty . \end{aligned}$$

Therefore, from the system of conservation laws (4.12)–(4.15) we get step by step for all \(1 \leqslant q < \infty \)

$$\begin{aligned}&\vec \Phi \in W^{2,q}_{\mathrm {loc}}(B_{1/2}(0), {\mathbb {R}}^3), \qquad \nabla \vec n \in L^q_{\mathrm {loc}}(B_{1/2}(0), ({\mathbb {R}}^3)^2), \\&Y \in W^{2,q}_{\mathrm {loc}}(B_{1/2}(0), {\mathbb {R}}), \\&\vec R \in W^{2,q}_{\mathrm {loc}}(B_{1/2}(0), {\mathbb {R}}^3), \qquad S \in W^{2,q}_{\mathrm {loc}}(B_{1/2}(0), {\mathbb {R}}). \end{aligned}$$

Iteration gives

$$\begin{aligned} \vec \Phi \in W^{k,p}_{\mathrm {loc}}(B_{1/2}(0), {\mathbb {R}}^3) \qquad \text {for all } k \in {\mathbb {N}}, \, 1 \leqslant p < \infty \end{aligned}$$

and hence,

$$\begin{aligned} \vec \Phi \in C^\infty (B_{1/2}(0)), \end{aligned}$$

which finishes the proof. \(\quad \square \)

Let \(A_0, V_0 > 0\) satisfy the isoperimetric inequality: \(A_0^3 \geqslant 36 \pi V_0^2\) and let

$$\begin{aligned} {\mathcal {F}}_{A_0, V_0} := {\mathcal {F}} \cap \{\vec \Phi : {{\,\mathrm{Area}\,}}\vec \Phi = A_0, \, {{\,\mathrm{Vol}\,}}\vec \Phi = V_0\} \end{aligned}$$

be the family of weak (possibly branched) immersions with area \(A_{0}\) and enclosed volume \(V_{0}\). Using the scaling invariance of the Willmore energy (which implies the equivalence between a scale invariant isoperimetric-ratio constraint versus a double constraint on enclosed volume and area), from [35, Lemma 2.1] we get that

$$\begin{aligned} \inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}_{A_{0},V_{0}} } \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H ^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }} < 8 \pi . \end{aligned}$$

Define

$$\begin{aligned} \varepsilon _{4.4}(A_{0},V_{0}) : = \dfrac{ \sqrt{8 \pi } - \sqrt{\inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}_{A_{0},V_{0}} } \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H ^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}}}{2 \sqrt{A_{0}}} \in \left( 0, (\sqrt{2}-1) \sqrt{\pi }/\sqrt{A_0} \right] ,\nonumber \\ \end{aligned}$$

(4.24)

where the upper bound is given by the Willmore theorem [42, Theorem 7.2.2], see also (2.13). Notice that \(\varepsilon _{4.4}(A_{0},V_{0})\) depends continuously on \(A_{0}\) and \(V_{0}\). Indeed, from [35, Theorem 1.1], \(\inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}_{A_{0},V_{0}} } \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H ^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}\) is a continuous function of the isoperimetric ratio.

Lemma 4.4

Let \(A_{0}> 0, V_{0} >0\) satisfy the isoperimetric inequality: \(A_{0}^{3} \geqslant 36 \pi V_{0}^{2}\) and let \(\varepsilon _{4.4}=\varepsilon _{4.4}(A_{0},V_{0})\) be defined as in (4.24). Then, for any \(c_{0} \in (-\varepsilon _{4.4}, \varepsilon _{4.4})\), the following holds.

Any minimizing sequence \(\vec {\Phi }_{k}\) of \(\inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}_{A_{0},V_{0}} } \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} ( H - c_{0} )^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}\) satisfies

$$\begin{aligned} \limsup _{k \rightarrow + \infty } \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H_{\vec \Phi _k}^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }_{k}} < 8 \pi . \end{aligned}$$

Proof

From the Cauchy–Schwartz inequality, we have \(\vert \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }} \vert \leqslant \sqrt{\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}} \sqrt{\text {Area}({\vec {\Phi }})}\). Thus:

$$\begin{aligned} \left( \sqrt{\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}} - \vert c_{0} \vert \sqrt{ \text {Area}({\vec {\Phi }}) } \right) ^{2}\leqslant & {} \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} (H-c_{0})^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}\\\leqslant & {} \left( \sqrt{\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}} + \vert c_{0} \vert \sqrt{ \text {Area}({\vec {\Phi }})} \right) ^{2}, \end{aligned}$$

which yields

$$\begin{aligned} \left| \sqrt{\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}}- \sqrt{\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} (H-c_{0})^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}} \right| \leqslant \vert c_{0} \vert \sqrt{ \text {Area}({\vec {\Phi }})}. \end{aligned}$$

(4.25)

In particular, we deduce that

$$\begin{aligned} \left| \inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}_{A_{0},V_{0}}} \sqrt{ \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}} - \inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}_{A_{0},V_{0}}} \sqrt{\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} (H-c_{0})^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}} \right| \leqslant \vert c_{0} \vert \sqrt{A_{0}}. \end{aligned}$$

(4.26)

Let \(c_{0}\in (- \varepsilon _{4.4}(A_{0},V_{0}), \varepsilon _{4.4}(A_{0},V_{0}))\) and let \(\vec {\Phi }_{k}\) be a minimizing sequence of \(\inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}_{A_{0},V_{0}} } \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} ( H - c_{0} )^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}\).

For k large enough, it holds that

$$\begin{aligned}&\sqrt{\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} ( H_k - c_{0} )^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }_{k}}} \nonumber \\&\quad \leqslant \sqrt{\inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}_{A_{0},V_{0}}} \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} (H-c_{0})^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}}+ (\varepsilon _{4.4}(A_{0},V_{0})- \vert c_{0} \vert ) \sqrt{A_{0}}. \end{aligned}$$

(4.27)

Combining (4.25)–(4.27), we get

$$\begin{aligned}&\displaystyle {\sqrt{\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H_k^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }_{k}}}} \\&\quad \leqslant \sqrt{\int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} (H_k- c_{0})^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }_{k}}} + \vert c_{0} \vert \sqrt{A_{0}} \\&\quad \leqslant \sqrt{\inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}_{A_{0},V_{0}}} \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} (H-c_{0})^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}} + (\varepsilon _{4.4}(A_{0},V_{0})- \vert c_{0} \vert ) \sqrt{A_{0}} + \vert c_{0} \vert \sqrt{A_{0}}\\&\quad < \sqrt{\inf _{\vec {\Phi } \in {\mathcal {F}}_{A_{0},V_{0}}} \int \nolimits _{{\mathbb {S}}^2} H^{2} \, {\mathrm{d}}\mu _{\vec {\Phi }}} + 2\varepsilon _{4.4}(A_{0},V_{0}) \sqrt{A_{0}} = \sqrt{8 \pi }, \end{aligned}$$

where in the last identity we plugged in the definition of \(\varepsilon _{4.4}(A_{0},V_{0}) \) as in (4.24). \(\quad \square \)
